title: FRQ Score
stimulusHtml:
I. Always begin with the regular scoring guide. Try an alternate scoring guide only if necessary. (See E below.)

A. Using the regular scoring guide, award 1 point for each segment correct in both pitch and rhythm. Note that:

· A “segment” is

o in simple duple or compound duple meter: any half measure of the original melody , even if occurring over a bar line or beginning on a metrically weak pulse. (In common time or cut time, a segment is any set of two contiguous quarter-note beats; in compound duple meter, a segment is any set of three contiguous eighth-note beats.)

o in simple triple meter: a full measure of the original melody , even if occurring over a bar line or beginning on a metrically weak pulse. (In simple triple meter, a segment is any set of three contiguous quarter-note beats.)

· To receive credit, a segment must not overlap with any other segment receiving credit.

· Do not subdivide a note to identify a segment.

· To receive credit, a segment may be metrically shifted from its original position.

· Give no credit for the final note if notation of pitches continues thereafter.

B. If at least one segment is correct in pitch and rhythm, award 1 extra point to the total. For example, a response that is correct in all aspects receives a score of 8 + 1 = 9. Exception: Do not award a 9 unless all measures have the correct number of beats. Award an 8 (i.e., do not award the extra point) to an otherwise perfect response that does not use bar lines correctly.

C. The following notations will not receive credit: enharmonic equivalents; octave transpositions; dots before the notehead; accidentals after the notehead.

D. Record any score of 4 or higher and disregard the alternate scoring guides.

E. If after applying A–C the score is less than 4, try an alternate scoring guide.

F. If you try both regular and alternate scoring guides, award the higher of the scores if there is a difference.

G. Scores from the regular scoring guide may not be combined with those from an alternate scoring guide and vice versa.

II. Alternate Scoring Guides (Do not award the additional correct segment point.)

A. Award ½ point per segment of correct pitches. (Maximum of 4 points)

OR

B. Award ¼ point per segment of correct rhythm. (Maximum of 2 points)

III. Rounding fractional scores (applies only to Alternate Scoring Guides):

A. Half-point totals round down with one exception: A total score of 1½ rounds up to 2.

B. Quarter points should be rounded to the closest integer.

For ease of scoring, the Alternate Scoring Guidelines have been accounted for in the point-value options presented.
descriptions:
None of the segments are correct in either pitch or rhythm. [Regular Scoring]

OR

Only one segment is correct in pitch. [Alternate Scoring]

OR

Only one or two segments are correct in rhythm. [Alternate Scoring]

No segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm; two segments are correct in pitch but not in rhythm [Alternate Scoring].

OR

No segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm; three to five segments are correct in rhythm but not in pitch [Alternate Scoring].

One segment is correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

OR

None of the segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. Three to five segments are correct in pitch but not in rhythm [Alternate Scoring].

OR

None of the segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. Six to eight segments are correct in rhythm but not in pitch [Alternate Scoring].

Two segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

OR

None of the segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. Six or seven segments are correct in pitch but not in rhythm [Alternate Scoring].

Three segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

OR

None of the segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. All eight segments are correct in pitch but not in rhythm [Alternate Scoring].
Four segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].
Five segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].
Six segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

Seven segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

OR

All eight segments are correct in pitch and rhythm but bar lines are used incorrectly (not all measures have the correct number of beats) [Regular Scoring].
Eight segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].
